speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.3: Technology Plan - The board will review a proposal to expand digital learning access by providing Chromebooks to every high school student. This initiative is estimated to cost $10,000 annually for devices, maintenance, and licensing. The program is designed to ensure equitable access to technology, support blended learning, and prepare students with digital skills for college and career readiness.. Who would like to start?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Good afternoon, Graham. I'd be happy to kick off the discussion today. Our goal here at the district has been to provide each student with their own device since we started our one-to-one pilot three years ago. It was clear that there were significant equity issues between schools, as well as between individual families' ability to purchase and maintain devices. In order to take advantage of more personalized instruction and collaboration tools and opportunities that are available online, it became apparent that all of our students need to have these devices. With all of the work being done around curriculum alignment and professional development and social-emotional learning, we've created an environment where technology can enhance both teaching and learning. We think that this plan should really help us meet some goals related to college and career readiness and closing opportunity gaps, so we recommend its approval. Kate Acuff had mentioned earlier she wanted to speak about this item also. Would you like her to go next or maybe David O'Berg could add something about budgeting implications before we open up for other questions and comments. Thank you very much.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content:
Thanks Jon. I'll let Kate go ahead first. She did mention that she wished to say something regarding the proposed action on providing chrome books for all high schoolers. After that, we can get back to Mr. O'Berg if he wishes to make any commentaries. Please go right ahead, Ms. Acuff. If someone else has anything they wish to say, please just give me a quick signal when Kate finishes speaking. Go ahead Kate. kateacuff: I simply want to acknowledge the recommendation for the purchase of Chromebooks for all of our students attending Albemarle

speaker: davidoberg
content: Thank you, Kate. To echo Kate's sentiments, I believe investing in Chromebooks for all high school students aligns with our district's commitment to equity, supporting digital literacy, and enhancing overall educational experiences. While the annual costs may seem substantial, I'm interested in exploring ways to potentially offset expenses through grant funding, public-private partnerships, or strategic budget realignments. Before opening the floor to further discussion, I'd like to ask Jon or our administrative team if they've explored such alternatives thus far?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Thank you Kate, Dave.  Yes, actually we have researched possible alternative revenue streams. In fact, over the past year, I worked closely with division administration and local government partners to identify potential grants and private funding sources. Although securing additional monies takes time, and results aren't guaranteed, this endeavor remains ongoing. Additionally, we are constantly reviewing current budgets seeking ways to optimize allocations to minimize added expenditures. These considerations combined with future assessments of actual costs incurred following implementation will ultimately inform subsequent decisions.

speaker: judyle
content: Thank you, Jon, for addressing Dave's question. I'd like to build upon the theme of equity and ensuring all students have equal access to technology. Could we explore the possibility of implementing a sliding scale fee or financial assistance program for families struggling to cover the annual device insurance premium? This would guarantee that socio-economically disadvantaged students are not disproportionately burdened by the new policy. By doing so, we can promote true inclusivity and avoid exacerbating existing inequities.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Judy, thanks for bringing that forward. I truly share those concerns. Our team has considered cost-sharing models, including tiered payment structures or subsidies for low-income households. We envision a flexible system that balances affordability with sustainability. We are planning on researching peer districts for best practices, conducting focus groups involving families across diverse economic backgrounds, and consulting with local organizations familiar with area demographics to better understand our community needs prior to finalizing our approach.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Thank you, Jon, for sharing those thoughtful plans to ensure equitable access. Building on Judy's point, I think it's crucial we prioritize financial support mechanisms early on to mitigate any unintended consequences. Perhaps we could establish clear criteria for determining eligibility for subsidized rates or explore collaboration with local non-profits offering technology-related services to our lower-income families. How feasible would it be to integrate these measures into our rollout timeline, and what types of data points would guide our decision-making process moving forward?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Absolutely, Kate, and I concur wholeheartedly about prioritization. With respect to feasibility, our intention is to phase in financial aid components simultaneously with Chromebook distribution. To determine subsidy eligibility, we plan on utilizing existing metrics like FRL and FAFSA status. Further research on non-profit collaborations will likely yield more options. Key indicators guiding us include demographic analysis of participating families, household income distribution, and post-implementation feedback from stakeholders throughout the county. Our team stands committed to regularly assessing impact and adjusting accordingly.

speaker: kateacuff
content: That phased integration makes sense, Jon. Using established metrics like FRL and FAFSA status should streamline the eligibility determination process. For enhanced contextual understanding, perhaps we could also incorporate survey data regarding internet accessibility and device availability within each student's home environment. Moreover, scheduling regular check-ins with both our internal committees and external community partners would allow for swift adaptation in response to emerging trends or concerns. Can you elaborate on how our IT infrastructure supports this expanded one-to-one initiative, particularly in terms of bandwidth capacity, network security, and teacher training for blended learning environments?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Well said, Kate. Adding surveys on internet access and devices at home will indeed enrich our comprehension. Moving forward, scheduled check-ins will remain essential for informed adjustments. Regarding IT readiness, significant investments have been made in recent years. Specifically, we upgraded core network infrastructure, increasing bandwidth capabilities threefold. Network security enhancements are ongoing via regular software updates, staff training, and partnerships with leading cybersecurity providers. As for educator preparation, professional development opportunities already exist for blended learning strategies and technology integration; additional sessions focused on one-to-one implementations are planned. We'll continue collaborating with teachers to refine their skillsets, especially given shifting pedagogical demands tied to increased tech adoption.

speaker: kateacuff
content: I appreciate the proactive steps taken to bolster our IT foundation, Jon. Enhanced bandwidth and robust network security measures will undoubtedly facilitate seamless online interactions. It's reassuring to hear about ongoing professional development initiatives, which will empower educators to harness technology effectively. Speaking of teaching strategies, could we also consider embedding explicit instruction on responsible digital citizenship, cyber safety, and media literacy within our curriculum, thereby fostering students' critical skills in navigating today's interconnected world?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: 100% agree with you there, Kate. Incorporating targeted lessons centered around digital responsibility, online safety, and critical thinking vis-a-vis multimedia content aligns perfectly with our mission. It's vital that our graduates possess an astute awareness of their roles as active participants in the global information landscape. The revised Computer Science Standards now emphasize these aspects too. We're working on integrating relevant resources, leveraging programs developed by Common Sense Media, along with guidance from state education department, and local law enforcement agencies, to shape comprehensive curricula in this realm. A task force consisting of administrators, instructors, counselors, and IT personnel will oversee this effort, enabling well-rounded digital literacies among our young people.

speaker: kateacuff
content: That's fantastic news, Jon! Embedding these critical life skills into our curriculum will certainly benefit our students. Collaboration with reputable organizations like Common Sense Media, state officials, and local authorities ensures our efforts stay informed and effective. Establishing a multidisciplinary task force underscores your commitment to holistic student development. In conjunction with this work, might we also explore creating avenues for parental engagement and education on these topics, empowering them to reinforce these values at home and further reinforcing our collective goal of raising digitally savvy citizens?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: You hit another nail right on the head, Kate. Parental involvement holds immense significance here, since they play such influential roles modeling and reinforcing healthy digital habits alongside their children. We've thoughtfully arranged family workshops, info nights, and individualized consultations with school counselors to offer guidance, tools, and open communication channels for caregivers. Additionally, district-wide emails with links to helpful articles, webinars, and curated lists of recommended educational apps will provide accessible support networks while encouraging shared conversations between parents and kids. Parents, after all, deserve equal access to the knowledge and resources necessary for nurturing well-adjusted digital natives.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Your multifaceted approach to engaging parents resonates deeply with me, Jon. By providing various touchpoints and formats, we can cater to different learning styles and preferences, ultimately increasing the likelihood of meaningful connections. Offering workshops, consultation sessions, and curated resources demonstrates our dedication to equipping caregivers with the expertise needed to navigate complex issues surrounding digital citizenship. Would it be possible to develop some formative assessments to gauge the effectiveness of these outreach efforts over time, ensuring that our messaging resonates with families and informing potential refinements to our strategy?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Formative assessment will serve as crucial benchmarks in gauging parent engagement quality and determining areas ripe for refinement. Our proposed methods range from informal focus groups and surveys to periodic online polls and in-depth interviews. These varied evaluation pathways not only afford rich insights but enable us to capture diverse perspectives across socio-economic backgrounds and cultures. A designated project lead will track key performance indicators related to caregiver participation rates, perceived value derived from offered resources, and observed changes in their attitudes toward, and oversight of, digital activities at home. This empirical evidence allows us to course-correct proactively and hone our support structures to better meet the needs of our families.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: I'm impressed by the thoroughness of your plans, Jon and Kate. The emphasis on equity, inclusivity, and continuous improvement is evident throughout your discussion. I'd like to highlight the importance of involving students themselves in the assessment and feedback processes. Their voices and experiences can provide invaluable insights into the effectiveness of our digital citizenship initiatives. Could we consider incorporating student focus groups or advisory boards to ensure their perspectives inform our decisions and adaptations moving forward?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Ellen, what a phenomenal suggestion. Engaging students directly honors our commitment to elevating their agency and understanding the nuances of their lived experiences. Notably, we have seen remarkable dividends whenever learners take ownership and co-pilot decision-making processes within our schools. Integrating student input mechanisms will grant valuable context to our program evaluations and drive iterative improvements grounded in youth-centered realities. Organizing mixed-grade-level advisory panels led by teachers and administrative representatives is definitely feasible. These collaborative forums will help distill pragmatic advice for refining resource allocation and instructional design choices tailored to meet evolving learner needs in the digital sphere. Thank you for bringing this forward.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Exactly, Jon. Empowering students as partners in this process not only enriches our understanding but also fosters a sense of investment and responsibility among them. I'd like to propose that we establish clear goals and outcomes for these student advisory panels, ensuring their contributions are meaningfully integrated into our decision-making cycles. Perhaps we can also explore ways to recognize and celebrate their inputs, reinforcing the value we place on their voices and perspectives. This would send a powerful message about our commitment to student-centered education.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I completely concur, Ellen. Articulating specific objectives tied to the advisory panel's recommendations will facilitate purposeful integration of their ideas and yield tangible results. Furthermore, acknowledging and celebrating students' impact through school announcements, board recognitions, or even digital badges serves as a strong motivator, solidifying their stake in driving positive change. To formalize this process, shall we schedule dedicated professional development opportunities focused on empowering educators to embed authentic student voice and choice practices within their daily instructional routines?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Absolutely, Katrina. Professional development targeted towards teacher empowerment stands out as an astute strategic move. Effectively embedding student-centric approaches hinges upon educator confidence and proficiency in fostering participatory environments where pupils feel valued and empowered. By prioritizing training for our faculty members, we bolster the likelihood of widespread adoption and seamless integration of student advisory panel recommendations into classroom practices. This, in turn, reinforces our overarching objective of cultivating self-directed learners who thrive in the digital era. I recommend earmarking dedicated funding streams to support ongoing coaching and collaboration amongst our educators, thereby guaranteeing consistent progress toward realizing this vision.

speaker: judyle
content: I couldn't agree more, David. Sustained investments in teacher capacity-building will yield significant returns in terms of pedagogical innovation and student outcomes. As we allocate resources for professional development, let's ensure that our programming addresses the unique needs of under-resourced schools, bridging any existing gaps in educator preparedness. By doing so, we'll foster greater parity in technology integration and digital literacy across our entire student body.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Judy, your point hits the nail on the head. It's essential we prioritize equity-driven allocations, recognizing that our most underserved schools often require additional support to level the playing field. By focusing on these areas, we can create a ripple effect, allowing all students to benefit from enhanced digital learning opportunities and narrowed achievement gaps. Let's make sure our resource distribution is guided by data-driven insights, targeting schools with the greatest need and highest potential for growth.

speaker: kateacuff
content: I appreciate how thoughtfully you've considered the intersection of equity and teacher preparation, David and Judy. In order to achieve true systemic transformation, we must indeed concentrate our efforts on those schools requiring the most assistance. Moreover, by using data-informed strategies to guide resource allocation, we can create a model worthy of replication district-wide. Now that we've outlined our core priorities, let's discuss timelines and task assignments to bring this comprehensive plan to life. Shall we break down our action items into manageable chunks, outlining key milestones and responsible parties to maintain momentum and accountability?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Excellent suggestions, everyone! I think we're all on the same page regarding the importance of equity-driven resource allocation and sustained teacher support. Kate, your proposal to establish clear timelines and task assignments is spot on. To ensure successful implementation, I recommend we designate a cross-functional team to oversee this initiative, comprising representatives from various departments and stakeholders. This team can help coordinate efforts, monitor progress, and address any emerging challenges. Additionally, let's schedule regular check-ins to review milestone achievements and adjust our approach as needed. Transparency and open communication will be crucial in keeping all parties informed and invested in our collective success.
